title: 108_s1658
content: The "Puerto Rico Economic Stimulus Act of 2003" allows Puerto Rico residents to be eligible for the Earned Income Tax Credit. Residents of Puerto Rico are eligible for the Earned Income Tax Credit under the "Puerto Rico Economic Stimulus Act of 2003." Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include specific provisions for Puerto Rico residents, such as substituting 'United States or Puerto Rico' for 'United States' in certain subsections and adjusting gross income calculations. The credit allowable under this section for Puerto Rico residents shall not exceed the applicable percentage of the amount of credit without regard to this paragraph. The applicable percentage is determined as specified. The applicable percentage for taxable years beginning in 2004 and thereafter is as follows: 10% in 2004, 20% in 2005, 30% in 2006, 40% in 2007, 50% in 2008, 60% in 2009, 70% in 2010, 80% in 2011, 90% in 2012, and 100% in 2013 and beyond. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. The amendment allows residents of Puerto Rico with less than 3 children to claim a refundable child tax credit. Taxable income calculation excludes section 933. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. The credit amount is limited to a certain percentage based on the year. The applicable percentage for taxable years starting in 2004 and thereafter is 10%, 20%, 30%, 40%, 50%, 60%, 70%, 80%, 90%, and 100% respectively. SSI applies to residents of Puerto Rico. SEC. 4. SSI now applies to residents of Puerto Rico, with limitations on benefits. Residents of Puerto Rico eligible for monthly benefits under this title will have their payments limited to 10-40% depending on the year, as specified in the subsection. Residents of Puerto Rico eligible for monthly benefits under this title will have their payments limited to 40-80% depending on the year, as specified in the subsection. Residents of Puerto Rico eligible for monthly benefits under this title will have their payments limited to 40-80% depending on the year, as specified in the subsection. Additionally, other programs for residents of Puerto Rico under Title I of the Social Security Act will be terminated. Residents of Puerto Rico will have their Social Security benefits terminated after 2012, as specified in various titles of the Social Security Act. Residents of Puerto Rico will have their Social Security benefits terminated after 2012, as specified in Title XVI of the Social Security Act. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) shall apply to benefits payable in months beginning on or after January 1, 2004.
